content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

This is a game of simultaneous moves known as a "Stag Hunt" or "Chicken" game, where cooperation (choosing the same symbol) can result in a higher reward, but there's also the risk of losing out if both players choose differently.

In this case, if I always choose R and my anonymous opponent chooses B, they get 35$ per round while I get nothing. On the other hand, if we both choose R, we each get 45$. However, if we both choose B, we both get a lower payout of 40$, but that's still better than getting nothing by choosing R when the opponent chooses B.

Given that this is a one-time game and I don't know the opponent's strategy, it would seem rational to try and maximize my potential payoff. Choosing R gives me a higher reward if the opponent also chooses R (45$), while choosing B only guarantees a payout of 40$. Therefore, my choice would be R {R}.

However, in a repeated game scenario or when I have some information about the opponent's strategy, my decision might change. In this specific case with 75 rounds and no prior knowledge, it seems reasonable to pick R as my initial strategy, but the optimal strategy could change over time depending on how the game unfolds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, my initial choice of R did not result in cooperation with my opponent who chose B instead. I received a payout of 0$ while my opponent earned 35$.

Given that I now have some information about my opponent's strategy and the fact that they benefited more from our non-cooperation, it might be rational to adjust my strategy in the next round to try to maximize my potential payoff. In this case, choosing B would guarantee me a payout of 40$ if my opponent also chooses B, which is better than receiving nothing for choosing R when they chose B. Therefore, my choice for the next round would be B {B}.

Again, it's important to note that in a repeated game scenario or if I had more information about my opponent's strategy, my decision might change. But with limited knowledge and only one more round, it seems reasonable to adjust my strategy based on the outcome of the previous round.
